Award.AwardTitle: Spectroscopy of Rydberg Atoms in Optical Lattices and Laser Traps
Award.AbstractNarration:
Physicists at the University of Michigan are useing "ponderomotive spectroscopy," an advanced form of a technique that traces back at least to the 17th century when Isaac Newton first showed that white light sent through a prism breaks into a rainbow. The new high-resolution spectroscopy allows the researchers to peer more deeply into the structure of atoms and direct their behavior at a much finer scale. The measurements made possible by ponderomotive spectroscopy could thus lead to advances in fundamental physics and promote the progress of science. In their research, the scientists use Rydberg atoms--giant atoms that exhibit not only greater size, but also stronger interactions than usual atoms. Rydberg atoms enable the new method of ponderomotive spectroscopy. In addition, they allow for the detection of small electromagnetic fields, which may improve our ability to measure natural or human activity, as well as investigate how systems of quantum-mechanical matter (matter that behaves like waves) interact with each other.

In detail, the researchers employ a spectroscopic method in which highly excited Rydberg atoms are prepared in a modulated optical-lattice laser trap. Laser-cooled ground-state atoms are excited into Rydberg levels within the optical lattice. The lattice field holds on to the tenuously bound Rydberg electron via the ponderomotive light-electron interaction, which in turn results in a trapping force for the entire atom. Time-dependent microwave modulation of the trapping field then drives transitions between Rydberg-atom levels whose energies are separated by odd harmonics of the modulation frequency. The frequency-resolution and accuracy limits of lattice modulation spectroscopy are explored. The method is employed to measure atomic quantities, such as quantum defects, ionic polarizabilities and the Rydberg constant. Using a cavity-generated, very deep implementation of the Rydberg-atom lattice, the energies of strongly mixed Rydberg adiabatic states are measured. Other measurement objectives are the polarizabilities of low-lying atomic levels and light propagation in the densely filled cold-atom channels present in the cavity-generated optical lattice. In a second research component, the trajectories of Rydberg-atom pairs are measured using a direct atom imaging technique, which is based on Rydberg-atom field ionization, ion extraction and spatial imaging. The trajectory measurements reveal interatomic forces and their anisotropy. The Rydberg-atom interactions are controlled via adiabatic passage in Landau-Zener crossings in the Rydberg-atom Stark map, which allows the preparation of dense, highly dipolar quantum matter.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Merit: Laser and radio-frequency (RF) spectroscopy of atoms and molecules lies at the heart of understanding matter, quantum-mechanical behavior, matter-light interactions and entanglement. The research in the field encompasses both fundamental and applied science. The work conducted within the realm of this project has been concerned with the fundamental physics of Rydberg atoms, which are highly excited atoms with a loosely bound valence electron, in laser traps and vapor-cell enclosures. These atoms form long-range molecules which are interesting due to their unusual binding mechanisms and their unusual properties. We have used them to learn about the scattering behavior between low-energy electrons and atoms. This is traditionally hard to do with electron and atomic beams due to technical difficulties. A Rydberg molecule, on the other hand, represent a natural laboratory for these studies because the Rydberg molecule incorporates a low-energy electron (the Rydberg valence electron) and an embedded atom. The particles undergo continual interaction within the molecule, making the low-energy electron collision comparatively easy to measure. In our detailed lab work, the molecular states have been measured using laser spectroscopy in an optical-lattice laser trap. The spectra have allowed us to extract the fundamentals of the electron-atom scattering process that binds the molecule. Similarly, spectroscopic studies of Rydberg-atom molecules formed by a pair of Rydberg atoms bound at a large distance have provided us with insight into another interesting molecular binding mechanism that is based on multipolar interactions. There, the atomic constituents interact due to long-range electrostatic forces that extend over distances well beyond the distance at which the atoms would touch (the so-called Le Roy radius). Further research has dealt with the interaction of Rydberg atoms with modulated laser light fields in optical lattices. This work was a continuation of pioneering work of the group on ponderomotive Rydberg-atom trapping and spectroscopy, a method that differs greatly from other spectroscopies in terms of its special quantum-mechanical foundations. In our recent work, a plan has been laid out and published of how to measure the Rydberg constant using circular Rydberg atoms in an intensity-modulated Rydberg-atom optical lattice.

Broader impact: Rydberg-atom optical lattices as used in this work can play a role in the development of quantum computing. Optical trapping large objects such as Rydberg atoms has some parallels with trapping mesoscopic particles (nanoparticles) in lattices. Optical modulation spectroscopy could possibly be applied to study large bio-molecules trapped in x-ray optical lattices. Rydberg atoms are excellent candidates as atomic field sensors and in emergent quantum technologies. In the project, graduate and undergraduate students are trained in research, research presentation, and in peer instruction. The project as a whole has a broader impact on society in that students at all levels become prepared to assume important tasks in science, industry and education. Students benefit from the research lab’s connections with NIST, Rydberg Technologies Inc., Shanxi University (Taiyuan, CN), and research groups in Germany. Three students graduated (Nithiwadee Thaicharoen, Kaitlin Moore, Stephanie Miller).
